    <itunes:title>Divorce Without Drama: How to Protect Your Kids in Divorce</itunes:title>
    <title>Divorce Without Drama: How to Protect Your Kids in Divorce</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[When her eight-year-old girl defined her parents' divorce as "good," Sarah Armstrong, VP of Global Marketing Operations at Google, knew she was on to something important. After her marriage dissolved, Sarah was determined to put her daughter first. She and her husband did that so well that now Sarah teaches others how to protect their kids in divorce, too. According to Sarah, the key to minimizing the damage to children in a divorce lies in parents developing a "compartmentalization muscle." ...]]></itunes:summary>
    <description><![CDATA[<p>When her eight-year-old girl defined her parents&apos; divorce as &quot;good,&quot; Sarah Armstrong, VP of Global Marketing Operations at Google, knew she was on to something important. After her marriage dissolved, Sarah was determined to put her daughter first. She and her husband did that so well that now Sarah teaches others how to protect their kids in divorce, too.</p><p>According to Sarah, the key to minimizing the damage to children in a divorce lies in parents developing a &quot;compartmentalization muscle.&quot; (i.e. the ability to set aside your own triggers and emotional reactions for your child&apos;s sake.)¬†</p><p>In this podcast episode, Sarah shares powerful examples of taking the high road, from showing up together at parent-teacher conferences to the seemingly small but crucial decisions like ensuring kids don&apos;t feel like &quot;professional travelers&quot; shuttling belongings between homes.</p><p>Sarah offers crucial mindset tips as well as simple, concrete strategies for developing communication that actually works: when to text, when to email, when to call, and how to batch topics so co-parenting stays clear without becoming constant. If your co-parent won‚Äôt meet you in the middle, Sarah outlines how to control the controllables, stop feeding the conflict, and keep the focus on your child‚Äôs stability.¬†</p><p>If you or anyone you know is divorcing with children, this podcast episode will give you the mindset shift you need and the practical guidance you crave to really protect your kids in divorce.</p><p><b>About Sarah</b></p><p>Sarah Armstrong has spent more than 25 years in global marketing and is now VP of Global Marketing Operations at Google. She is widely acknowledged as an industry leader in her area of expertise. She is also the author of <em>The Mom‚Äôs Guide to a Good Divorce</em>, appearing on more than 75 podcasts and other media. She lives in San Francisco.</p><p><b>Connect with Sarah</b></p><p>You can connect with Sarah on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/sarah-madden-armstrong/'>Sarah Madden Armstrong</a>. To learn more about Sarah visit her website at <a href='https://thejugglingact.com/'>The Juggling Act</a> or¬† <a href='https://www.momsguidetogooddivorce.com/'>The Mom&apos;s Guide to a Good Divorce</a>.¬† You can reach out to Sarah at sarah@thejugglingact.com.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times. You can check out Karen&apos;s videos on <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@karencovy95'>YouTube</a>.<br/><br/>You can connect with Karen on <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/karencovy/'>LinkedIn</a>, <a href='https://www.facebook.com/KarenCovy'>Facebook</a>, <a href='https://www.instagram.com/karencovylawyer/'>Instagram</a>, <a href='https://twitter.com/KarenCovy'>Twitter</a>, and on her own website at <a href='https://karencovy.com/'>karencovy.com</a>.<br/><br/><br/></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>When her eight-year-old girl defined her parents&apos; divorce as &quot;good,&quot; Sarah Armstrong, VP of Global Marketing Operations at Google, knew she was on to something important. After her marriage dissolved, Sarah was determined to put her daughter first. She and her husband did that so well that now Sarah teaches others how to protect their kids in divorce, too.</p><p>According to Sarah, the key to minimizing the damage to children in a divorce lies in parents developing a &quot;compartmentalization muscle.&quot; (i.e. the ability to set aside your own triggers and emotional reactions for your child&apos;s sake.)¬†</p><p>In this podcast episode, Sarah shares powerful examples of taking the high road, from showing up together at parent-teacher conferences to the seemingly small but crucial decisions like ensuring kids don&apos;t feel like &quot;professional travelers&quot; shuttling belongings between homes.</p><p>Sarah offers crucial mindset tips as well as simple, concrete strategies for developing communication that actually works: when to text, when to email, when to call, and how to batch topics so co-parenting stays clear without becoming constant. If your co-parent won‚Äôt meet you in the middle, Sarah outlines how to control the controllables, stop feeding the conflict, and keep the focus on your child‚Äôs stability.¬†</p><p>If you or anyone you know is divorcing with children, this podcast episode will give you the mindset shift you need and the practical guidance you crave to really protect your kids in divorce.</p><p><b>About Sarah</b></p><p>Sarah Armstrong has spent more than 25 years in global marketing and is now VP of Global Marketing Operations at Google.     <itunes:title>The Hidden Health Insurance Trap That Can Make Divorce Unaffordable</itunes:title>
    <title>The Hidden Health Insurance Trap That Can Make Divorce Unaffordable</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[You don‚Äôt lose money in divorce because you‚Äôre bad at math. You lose it because you make huge financial decisions while you‚Äôre emotionally overwhelmed and financially uneducated.     <description><![CDATA[<p>You don‚Äôt lose money in divorce because you‚Äôre bad at math. You lose it because you make huge financial decisions while you‚Äôre emotionally overwhelmed and financially uneducated. In this podcast episode, Leah Hadley, an accredited financial counselor, CDFA, and mediator, pulls back the curtain on the hidden health insurance traps and tax law changes scheduled to take effect in 2026 that may dramatically change your post-divorce financial future.</p><p>Leah explains how the tax and healthcare changes in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act may impact the amount you pay in taxes and, most significantly, in health insurance.</p><p>For example, experts are predicting that healthcare costs could increase by $1,000 or more <b><em>per month</em></b> in 2026 for those on marketplace insurance, making healthcare unaffordable for a significant percentage of the population. (‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs just ONE of the changes coming down the pike!)</p><p>On top of that, 2026 will bring tax law changes that, depending on your circumstances, can either make your financial future brighter or significantly more challenging.</p><p>Whether you‚Äôre just thinking about divorce or you‚Äôre already in the thick of it, understanding the changes that Leah explains in this podcast episode will be critical for your financial future.</p><p><b>About Leah</b></p><p>Leah Hadley is an Accredited Financial Counselor¬Æ, Certified Divorce Financial Analyst¬Æ, and Mediator who helps women navigate major life transitions with confidence and clarity. She‚Äôs the founder of Intentional Divorce Solutions and Intentional Wealth Partners, where she blends financial expertise with empathy to empower clients to make values-aligned decisions about their money and their future. Through her Intentional Divorce Insights podcast and workshops, Leah inspires women to create financial and emotional stability after divorce and beyond.</p><p><b>Connect with Leah</b></p><p>You can connect with Leah on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/leahahadley/'>Leah Hadley</a> and Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/intentionaldivorce'>Intentional Divorce Solutions</a>.¬† You can follow Leah on Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/intentionaldivorcesolutions'>Intentional Divorce Solutions,</a> on YouTube at <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@intentionaldivorceinsights'>Intentional Divorce Insights</a> and on her Podcast <a href='https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/intentional-divorce-insights/id1730374509'>Intentional Divorce Insights</a>.¬† To find out more about Leah‚Äôs work, visit her website at <a href='https://www.watchherthrive.co/about/'>Watch Her Thrive</a>.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <itunes:title>Your Sexless Marriage Isn&#39;t Dead: How to Rekindle Intimacy</itunes:title>
    <title>Your Sexless Marriage Isn&#39;t Dead: How to Rekindle Intimacy</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[The sex stopped, the silence started, and now you're strangers sharing a bed. In this podcast episode, marriage, sex, and intimacy coach Irene Fehr unpacks why passion so often cools in long-term marriages - and how you can rekindle intimacy in your sexless marriage without pressure, blame, or performance anxiety.  When Irene‚Äôs libido completely disappeared in her own marriage, she felt broken and alone. Her sexless marriage ultimately ended in divorce.     <description><![CDATA[<p>The sex stopped, the silence started, and now you&apos;re strangers sharing a bed. In this podcast episode, marriage, sex, and intimacy coach Irene Fehr unpacks why passion so often cools in long-term marriages - and how you can rekindle intimacy in your sexless marriage without pressure, blame, or performance anxiety.¬†</p><p>When Irene‚Äôs libido completely disappeared in her own marriage, she felt broken and alone. Her sexless marriage ultimately ended in divorce. Now Irene guides couples past the point where the passion in their relationship fades and helps them reconnect on every level, regardless of their age.</p><p>In this deep conversation, Irene reveals why so many couples slide into sexless marriages or roommate dynamics and the three most common mistakes couples make when trying to ‚Äúfix‚Äù their disappearing sex lives. Irene also tackles taboo realities, including mismatched desire, attraction changes, affairs, open marriages, and whether broken connection can genuinely be rebuilt.</p><p>If you and your spouse have slipped into being just ‚Äúroommates,‚Äù and you‚Äôre worried your marriage will either be eternally sexless, or end in divorce, listen to this podcast episode. Irene will show you how you can rekindle your passion (or rebuild it after an affair) so you can create the lasting intimacy you long for.</p><p><b>About Irene</b></p><p>Irene Fehr, MA, CPCC, SEP is a Marriage Sex &amp; Intimacy Coach who helps heterosexual couples make love and sex work over the long term ‚Äî including bringing passion back into a sexless relationship. Determined to dispel myths about why sex dies in a long-term relationship, her views have been featured globally in HuffPost, Cosmopolitan, Shape, Refinery29, ScaryMommy, EliteDaily, and Bustle. Through her coaching, she guides couples at different stages of the relationship via three core pathways ‚Äî Rekindling Us (rediscovering passion at midlife), Rebuilding Us (transforming crisis into connection), and Creating Us (laying a strong foundation for lasting love and sexual intimacy for new couples) ‚Äî always anchored in the principle of consciously and intentionally choosing ‚Äúus.‚Äù</p><p><b>Connect with Irene</b></p><p>You can connect with Irene on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/irenefehr'>Irene Fehr</a> and on Facebook at <a href='http://www.facebook.com/ignitedwoman'>Ignited Woman</a>.¬† You can follow Irene on Instagram at <a href='http://www.instagram.com/ignitedwoman'>Ignited Woman</a> and on her YouTube channel at <a href='http://www.youtube.com/ignitedwoman'>Ignited Woman</a>.¬† To find out how to work with Irene visit her website at <a href='http://www.irenefehr.com/'>Ignited Woman</a>.</p><p><b>Links to articles mentioned in podcast</b></p><p><a href='https://l.mailtrack.com/l/26d19ea25000a2679f26c549aacfd8c32f61a50f?u=5420610'>Why Your Partner Won‚Äôt Get Couples Counseling and How to Get Them On Board</a>¬†</p><p><a href='https://l.mailtrack.com/l/f7c6224b46c9f97a0c39d541f4d727d34e5ae0dd?u=5420610'>3 Warning Signs of Divorce and How to Address Them Before It&apos;s Too Late</a>¬†</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times. You can check out Karen&apos;s videos on <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@karencovy95'>YouTube</a>.<br/><br/>You can connect with Karen on <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/karencovy/'>LinkedIn</a>, <a href='https://www.facebook.com/KarenCovy'>Facebook</a>, <a href='https://www.instagram.com/karencovylawyer/'>Instagram</a>, <a href='https://twitter.com/KarenCovy'>Twitter</a>, and on her own website at <a href='https://karencovy.com/'>karencovy.com</a>.<br/><br/><br/></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>The sex stopped, the silence started, and now you&apos;re strangers sharing a bed. In this podcast episode, marriage, sex, and intimacy coach Irene Fehr unpacks why passion so often cools in long-term marriages - and how you can rekindle intimacy in your sexless marriage without pressure, blame, or performance anxiety.¬†</p><p>When Irene‚Äôs libido completely disappeared in her own marriage, she felt broken and alone. Her sexless marriage ultimately ended in divorce. Now Irene guides couples past the point where the passion in their relationship fades and helps them reconnect on every level, regardless of their age.</p><p>In this deep conversation, Irene reveals why so many couples slide into sexless marriages or roommate dynamics and the three most common mistakes couples make when trying to ‚Äúfix‚Äù their disappearing sex lives. Irene also tackles taboo realities, including mismatched desire, attraction changes, affairs, open marriages, and whether broken connection can genuinely be rebuilt.</p><p>If you and your spouse have slipped into being just ‚Äúroommates,‚Äù and you‚Äôre worried your marriage will either be eternally sexless, or end in divorce, listen to this podcast episode. Irene will show you how you can rekindle your passion (or rebuild it after an affair) so you can create the lasting intimacy you long for.</p><p><b>About Irene</b></p><p>Irene Fehr, MA, CPCC, SEP is a Marriage Sex &amp; Intimacy Coach who helps heterosexual couples make love and sex work over the long term ‚Äî including bringing passion back into a sexless relationship. Determined to dispel myths about why sex dies in a long-term relationship, her views have been featured globally in HuffPost, Cosmopolitan, Shape, Refinery29, ScaryMommy, EliteDaily, and Bustle. Through her coaching, she guides couples at different stages of the relationship via three core pathways ‚Äî Rekindling Us (rediscovering passion at midlife), Rebuilding Us (transforming crisis into connection), and Creating Us (laying a strong foundation for lasting love and sexual intimacy for new couples) ‚Äî always anchored in the principle of consciously and intentionally choosing ‚Äúus.‚Äù</p><p><b>Connect with Irene</b></p><p>You can connect with Irene on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/irenefehr'>Irene Fehr</a> and on Facebook at <a href='http://www.facebook.com/ignitedwoman'>Ignited Woman</a>.¬† You can follow Irene on Instagram at <a href='http://www.instagram.com/ignitedwoman'>Ignited Woman</a> and on her YouTube channel at <a href='http://www.youtube.com/ignitedwoman'>Ignited Woman</a>.¬† To find out how to work with Irene visit her website at <a href='http://www.irenefehr.com/'>Ignited Woman</a>.</p><p><b>Links to articles mentioned in podcast</b></p><p><a href='https://l.mailtrack.com/l/26d19ea25000a2679f26c549aacfd8c32f61a50f?u=5420610'>Why Your Partner Won‚Äôt Get Couples Counseling and How to Get Them On Board</a>¬†</p><p><a href='https://l.mailtrack.com/l/f7c6224b46c9f97a0c39d541f4d727d34e5ae0dd?u=5420610'>3 Warning Signs of Divorce and How to Address Them Before It&apos;s Too Late</a>¬†</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times. Eric explains the crucial differences between spousal benefits and survivor benefits and why understanding these distinctions matters for your financial future ‚Äì especially if you‚Äôre divorced.</p><p>Eric also clarifies the often-misunderstood rules around ex-spousal benefits, including the critical 10-year marriage requirement and how remarriage affects your eligibility to get Social Security benefits based on your ex‚Äôs status (‚Ä¶ which you can claim without your ex-spouse&apos;s knowledge or consent!)</p><p>Whether you&apos;re approaching retirement, recently divorced, or widowed, understanding these Social Security rules could mean the difference between financial struggle and financial security.</p><p><b>About Eric</b></p><p>Eric Blake is a CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER¬Æ professional and the founder of Blake Wealth Management, specializing in helping women 55+ navigate retirement with clarity and confidence.     <description><![CDATA[<p>Some decisions feel impossible - until you shrink them to the next doable step. Accountability coach <b>Jill Consor Beck</b> shares how tiny, sustainable actions can help you make massive decisions and manage tasks (like divorce) that seem overwhelming at first.¬†</p><p>Through daily text check-ins, Jill guides her clients through the mental clutter that keeps them stuck - whether they&apos;re navigating divorce, launching a side hustle, or simply trying to carve out 15 minutes for themselves in an impossibly packed day.</p><p>Jill‚Äôs accountability method breaks big, complicated ‚Äúto-dos‚Äù into bite-sized moves you can finish in minutes: like reviewing two pages of a large agreement each day, instead of endlessly procrastinating over reading the whole thing at once. She invites clients to practice ‚Äústrategic subtraction‚Äù (doing less to achieve more), to shift from extrinsic to intrinsic motivation, and to adopt a ‚Äúsurvive and advance‚Äù mindset when life gets messy.</p><p>If you can‚Äôt decide what to do because the decision you‚Äôre facing is too big, or if your divorce ‚Äúto-do‚Äù list has you totally paralyzed, this is podcast episode¬† can help you unlock your own mind and finally move forward.</p><p><b>About Jill</b></p><p>Jill Consor Beck is an accountability coach who gets it‚Äîshe spent 30 years in a pressure-cooker career, including 10 years in investment banking and 20 years in tech, running on Diet Coke and exhaustion while completely neglecting her own health. After hitting her breaking point and being diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis, she discovered how to make small, sustainable changes that transformed her life without guilt or overwhelm. She now coaches clients via text, holding them accountable through daily nudges that put them on a path to living the life they&apos;re entitled to‚Äîwhether that&apos;s getting physically healthy, making more time for mental health, taking steps toward financial well-being, or finally starting that side hustle they&apos;ve been talking about. Her approach isn&apos;t about adding more to your packed schedule; it&apos;s about creating accountability for the small daily choices that add up to the life you actually want to live.</p><p><b>Connect with Jill</b></p><p>You can connect with Jill on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/company/go-long'>Go Long</a> and on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/justgolong'>Just Go Long</a>.¬† You can follow Jill on X at <a href='https://x.com/JLCBeck'>JLC Beck</a>, on Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/justgolong/'>Just Go Long</a>¬†and on YouTube at <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@justgolongvideo'>Just Go Long Video</a>.   <item>
    <itunes:title>Gasping for Air: How to Deal with Narcissistic Abuse (ARCHIVE EPISODE)</itunes:title>
    <title>Gasping for Air: How to Deal with Narcissistic Abuse (ARCHIVE EPISODE)</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[WARNING: This episode might be triggering for anyone who has experienced or is trying to heal from domestic violence, sexual abuse, financial abuse or any type of intimate partner abuse. Listener discretion is advised. What if the love you've been desperately seeking could actually kill you? Dana Diaz knows this reality firsthand. She spent nearly three decades in a marriage where the emotional abuse was so severe that her body began to shut down. What‚Äôs worse is that the seeds of her sufferi...]]></itunes:summary>
    <description><![CDATA[<p><b>WARNING: This episode might be triggering for anyone who has experienced or is trying to heal from domestic violence, sexual abuse, financial abuse or any type of intimate partner abuse. Listener discretion is advised.</b></p><p>What if the love you&apos;ve been desperately seeking could actually kill you? Dana Diaz knows this reality firsthand. She spent nearly three decades in a marriage where the emotional abuse was so severe that her body began to shut down. What‚Äôs worse is that the seeds of her suffering were planted long before adulthood.</p><p>Raised by a distant, neglectful mother and an abusive stepfather, Dana grew up believing that love and pain were inseparable. That early conditioning left her vulnerable to repeating the same cycle in marriage, a cycle that would take her decades to escape.</p><p>When her marriage became abusive, she found herself accepting treatment she knew was wrong, because it was the only version of &quot;love&quot; she&apos;d ever known. The consequences were devastating. Her body produced such astronomically high levels of stress hormones that her immune system turned against her, leaving her skeletal, oxygen-dependent, and facing organ failure in her early 40s.</p><p>Through careful planning, hidden savings, and ultimately having the courage to choose herself, Dana escaped a situation that escalated to threats, gunshots, and a legal system that initially failed to protect her.¬†</p><p>Today, Dana is healthy, remarried, and dedicated to helping others recognize the signs of narcissistic abuse and reclaiming their lives. Her book <em>Gasping for Air: The Stranglehold of Narcissistic Abuse</em> chronicles her journey from victim to survivor to advocate, offering hope to anyone wondering if they deserve better.</p><p>This episode, which was originally published in October, 2023, is being replayed here to support Domestic Violence Awareness Month.</p><p><b>NOTE:</b> If you or someone you know is experiencing intimate partner abuse, please contact the domestic violence hotline as soon as possible.</p><p><b>National Domestic Violence Hotline 800-799-7233</b></p><p><b>About Dana</b></p><p>Dana studied journalism and psychology at DePaul University. She has also had life-long experiences with narcissistic abuse. Thankfully her education gave her the ability to accurately express how narcissistic abuse creates confusion and conflict within victims.¬†</p><p>Today, Dana is a proud voice for fellow victims who are unable, afraid, or too ashamed to share their experiences. She strives to create awareness and understanding to ensure victims are given the support they need to both understand their situation and heal from it.</p><p><b>Connect with Dana</b></p><p>You can learn more about Dana and her story on her website <a href='https://danasdiaz.com/'>Dana S Diaz.</a>¬† ¬†Dana also has a quiz to help you determine if you are in a relationship involving narcissistic abuse.<br/><br/>You can follow Dana on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/DanaSDiazAuthor/'>Dana S Diaz</a> and Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/danas.diaz/'>Dana S Diaz</a>.¬† You can get your copy of Dana&apos;s best-selling book, &quot;<a href='https://amzn.to/3PXFC2O'><em>Gasping for Air:¬† The Stranglehold of Narcissistic Abuse</em></a><em></em></p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times. You can check out Karen&apos;s videos on <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@karencovy95'>YouTube</a>.<br/><br/>You can connect with Karen on <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/karencovy/'>LinkedIn</a>, <a href='https://www.facebook.com/KarenCovy'>Facebook</a>, <a href='https://www.instagram.com/karencovylawyer/'>Instagram</a>, <a href='https://twitter.com/KarenCovy'>Twitter</a>, and on her own website at <a href='https://karencovy.com/'>karencovy.com</a>.<br/><br/><br/></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><b>WARNING: This episode might be triggering for anyone who has experienced or is trying to heal from domestic violence, sexual abuse, financial abuse or any type of intimate partner abuse. Listener discretion is advised.</b></p><p>What if the love you&apos;ve been desperately seeking could actually kill you? Dana Diaz knows this reality firsthand. She spent nearly three decades in a marriage where the emotional abuse was so severe that her body began to shut down. What‚Äôs worse is that the seeds of her suffering were planted long before adulthood.</p><p>Raised by a distant, neglectful mother and an abusive stepfather, Dana grew up believing that love and pain were inseparable. That early conditioning left her vulnerable to repeating the same cycle in marriage, a cycle that would take her decades to escape.</p><p>When her marriage became abusive, she found herself accepting treatment she knew was wrong, because it was the only version of &quot;love&quot; she&apos;d ever known. The consequences were devastating. Her body produced such astronomically high levels of stress hormones that her immune system turned against her, leaving her skeletal, oxygen-dependent, and facing organ failure in her early 40s.</p><p>Through careful planning, hidden savings, and ultimately having the courage to choose herself, Dana escaped a situation that escalated to threats, gunshots, and a legal system that initially failed to protect her.¬†</p><p>Today, Dana is healthy, remarried, and dedicated to helping others recognize the signs of narcissistic abuse and reclaiming their lives. Her book <em>Gasping for Air: The Stranglehold of Narcissistic Abuse</em> chronicles her journey from victim to survivor to advocate, offering hope to anyone wondering if they deserve better.</p><p>This episode, which was originally published in October, 2023, is being replayed here to support Domestic Violence Awareness Month.</p><p><b>NOTE:</b> If you or someone you know is experiencing intimate partner abuse, please contact the domestic violence hotline as soon as possible.</p><p><b>National Domestic Violence Hotline 800-799-7233</b></p><p><b>About Dana</b></p><p>Dana studied journalism and psychology at DePaul University. She has also had life-long experiences with narcissistic abuse. Thankfully her education gave her the ability to accurately express how narcissistic abuse creates confusion and conflict within victims.¬†</p><p>Today, Dana is a proud voice for fellow victims who are unable, afraid, or too ashamed to share their experiences. She strives to create awareness and understanding to ensure victims are given the support they need to both understand their situation and heal from it.</p><p><b>Connect with Dana</b></p><p>You can learn more about Dana and her story on her website <a href='https://danasdiaz.com/'>Dana S Diaz.</a>¬† ¬†Dana also has a quiz to help you determine if you are in a relationship involving narcissistic abuse.<br/><br/>You can follow Dana on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/DanaSDiazAuthor/'>Dana S Diaz</a> and Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/danas.diaz/'>Dana S Diaz</a>.¬† You can get your copy of Dana&apos;s best-selling book, &quot;<a href='https://amzn.to/3PXFC2O'><em>Gasping for Air:¬† The Stranglehold of Narcissistic Abuse</em></a><em></em></p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times. You can check out Karen&apos;s videos on <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@karencovy95'>YouTube</a>.<br/><br/>You can connect with Karen on <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/karencovy/'>LinkedIn</a>, <a href='https://www.facebook.com/KarenCovy'>Facebook</a>, <a href='https://www.instagram.com/karencovylawyer/'>Instagram</a>, <a href='https://twitter.com/KarenCovy'>Twitter</a>, and on her own website at <a href='https://karencovy.com/'>karencovy.com</a>.<br/><br/><br/></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <itunes:title>How to Heal From an Emotionally Abusive Marriage</itunes:title>
    <title>How to Heal From an Emotionally Abusive Marriage</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[What happens when divorce strips away not just your marriage, but your very sense of who you are? Licensed clinical social worker Debra Alper reveals why so many people emerge from divorce feeling completely lost ‚Äì especially when they‚Äôve been in emotionally abusive marriages.  Drawing from decades of experience, Debra explains the hidden process of self-erosion that starts long before the divorce papers are filed.     <description><![CDATA[<p><b>What happens when divorce strips away not just your marriage, but your very sense of who you are?</b> Licensed clinical social worker Debra Alper reveals why so many people emerge from divorce feeling completely lost ‚Äì especially when they‚Äôve been in emotionally abusive marriages.¬†</p><p>Drawing from decades of experience, Debra explains the hidden process of self-erosion that starts long before the divorce papers are filed. The slow buildup of unmet needs, quiet compromises, and unconscious bargains that happens in emotionally abusive marriages often leaves you disconnected from the core of your being.</p><p>When divorce happens, you find yourself not only grieving the relationship you lost, but also questioning your own identity. Healing from this kind of trauma isn‚Äôt just about getting through the legal or financial parts of divorce. It‚Äôs about reclaiming your voice and rebuilding your inner foundation.</p><p>From navigating high-conflict divorce and the grief that comes with it, to treating post-divorce dating as a learning lab, you‚Äôll discover how to move from reactivity to intentional choice. If you feel numb, overwhelmed, or unsure how to dream again, this podcast episode will give you permission to play, to daydream, and to let small wins stack into lasting change.¬†</p><p>It will show you how to heal, and how to love again.</p><p><b>About Debra</b></p><p>Debra Alper is a Licensed Clinical Social Worker and owner of Life Transitions Counseling, PLLC, specializing in relational therapy, helping clients to identify and recover from emotional abuse and divorce process and recovery. She has worked extensively since 1999 with individual clients striving to experience deeper, more meaningful relationships, couples in the midst of marital crisis around infidelity and unhappy, lonely relationships, and clients struggling to get through the emotional and life changing hurdles of pre and post-divorce. She also works extensively with clients in emotionally abusive relationships helping them to understand the dynamics that keep them stuck and aiding them in moving out of toxic patterns.</p><p><b>Connect with Debra</b></p><p>You can connect with Debra on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/debra-alper-lcsw-288960a2/'>Debra Alper, LCSW</a> and find out more about how to work with Debra by visiting her website at <a href='http://www.lifetransitionschicago.com/'>Life Transitions Chicago</a>.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Breakthrough Divorce Coaching, Anne, a divorcing mom caught in a three-year court battle, opens up about what it‚Äôs really like to navigate a high-conflict divorce when abuse, manipulation, and gaslighting don‚Äôt end just because your marriage does.¬†</p><p>Despite restraining orders and years of separation, Anne still finds herself fighting to protect her child‚Äôs safety and emotional well-being while trying to keep her own head above water. Her story exposes the toll that prolonged litigation and co-parenting with a toxic ex can take. It also illustrates the heartbreaking reality that the legal system isn‚Äôt built to solve these deeply human problems.¬†</p><p>Anne‚Äôs breakthrough comes when she starts to shift her focus from battling her ex to building her child‚Äôs resilience. Instead of pouring more money into a court system that can‚Äôt fix what‚Äôs broken, Anne explores how to empower her child with coping skills, emotional awareness, and a sense of safety that no court order can provide.¬†</p><p>What begins as a story about legal frustration turns into one of strength, insight, and breaking the cycle of abuse, showing that sometimes, the most powerful victory is raising a child who knows their own worth.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <itunes:title>How to Transform Your Marriage in One Weekend</itunes:title>
    <title>How to Transform Your Marriage in One Weekend</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[What if one weekend could deliver the clarity and progress of months of traditional marriage counseling? In this podcast episode, licensed clinical counselor Ann Cerny reveals a revolutionary approach to couples therapy that combines cutting-edge brain science with personalized intensive sessions that can transform your marriage, no matter how far gone you think it is.     <description><![CDATA[<p>What if one weekend could deliver the clarity and progress of months of traditional marriage counseling? In this podcast episode, licensed clinical counselor Ann Cerny reveals a revolutionary approach to couples therapy that combines cutting-edge brain science with personalized intensive sessions that can transform your marriage, no matter how far gone you think it is.¬†</p><p>Her weekend retreats go far beyond typical weekly therapy sessions, offering hope for marriages on the brink of separation through a carefully curated experience that addresses the deepest patterns keeping couples stuck.</p><p>During her intensive weekend format, Ann guides couples through transformational exercises that teach them how to truly listen and speak while managing their own reactive patterns at the same time.</p><p>For couples considering whether their relationship is salvageable, Anne offers a powerful reframe: the question isn&apos;t whether your marriage is fixable, but rather how committed you are to doing the work and examining your own contribution to the dynamic.¬†</p><p>If you and your spouse are struggling to keep your marriage together, and traditional marriage counseling isn‚Äôt working for you, this episode just might change your marriage ‚Ä¶ and your life.</p><p><b>About Ann</b></p><p>Ann is a licensed clinical counselor in both Illinois and California. She specializes in couples therapy for people who are interested in changing their dynamics today, and need it to stick. For couples who are ready for deep and lasting change, Ann&apos;s couples intensives are a personalized experience for one couple at a time, in Sausalito and Palm Desert, California. It is ideal for couples who are in crisis or considering separation, are healing from betrayal or emotional distance, want to rebuild trust and intimacy, or need focused time but can&apos;t commit to weekly therapy. One dedicated weekend can deliver the clarity and progress of months of therapy, because the relationship gets curated time and attention it needs and deserves.</p><p><b>Connect with Ann</b></p><p>You can connect with Ann on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/anncerneylcpc/'>Ann Cerney</a> and follow Ann on Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/cerneycoaching/'>Cerney Coaching</a>.¬† To find out more about Ann‚Äôs work visit her website at <a href='https://cerneycoaching.com/'>Cerney Coaching</a>.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times. You can check out Karen&apos;s videos on <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@karencovy95'>YouTube</a>.<br/><br/>You can connect with Karen on <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/karencovy/'>LinkedIn</a>, <a href='https://www.facebook.com/KarenCovy'>Facebook</a>, <a href='https://www.instagram.com/karencovylawyer/'>Instagram</a>, <a href='https://twitter.com/KarenCovy'>Twitter</a>, and on her own website at <a href='https://karencovy.com/'>karencovy.com</a>.<br/><br/><br/></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>What if one weekend could deliver the clarity and progress of months of traditional marriage counseling? In this podcast episode, licensed clinical counselor Ann Cerny reveals a revolutionary approach to couples therapy that combines cutting-edge brain science with personalized intensive sessions that can transform your marriage, no matter how far gone you think it is.¬†</p><p>Her weekend retreats go far beyond typical weekly therapy sessions, offering hope for marriages on the brink of separation through a carefully curated experience that addresses the deepest patterns keeping couples stuck.</p><p>During her intensive weekend format, Ann guides couples through transformational exercises that teach them how to truly listen and speak while managing their own reactive patterns at the same time.</p><p>For couples considering whether their relationship is salvageable, Anne offers a powerful reframe: the question isn&apos;t whether your marriage is fixable, but rather how committed you are to doing the work and examining your own contribution to the dynamic.¬†</p><p>If you and your spouse are struggling to keep your marriage together, and traditional marriage counseling isn‚Äôt working for you, this episode just might change your marriage ‚Ä¶ and your life.</p><p><b>About Ann</b></p><p>Ann is a licensed clinical counselor in both Illinois and California. She specializes in couples therapy for people who are interested in changing their dynamics today, and need it to stick. For couples who are ready for deep and lasting change, Ann&apos;s couples intensives are a personalized experience for one couple at a time, in Sausalito and Palm Desert, California. It is ideal for couples who are in crisis or considering separation, are healing from betrayal or emotional distance, want to rebuild trust and intimacy, or need focused time but can&apos;t commit to weekly therapy. One dedicated weekend can deliver the clarity and progress of months of therapy, because the relationship gets curated time and attention it needs and deserves.</p><p><b>Connect with Ann</b></p><p>You can connect with Ann on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/anncerneylcpc/'>Ann Cerney</a> and follow Ann on Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/cerneycoaching/'>Cerney Coaching</a>.¬† To find out more about Ann‚Äôs work visit her website at <a href='https://cerneycoaching.com/'>Cerney Coaching</a>.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <description><![CDATA[<p>Thirteen years of marriage, seven years of sacrifice, nine months of hell ‚Äì and now she faces the hardest choice of her life. Toki Simmons, a business leader who ‚Äúhas it all together,‚Äù shares the raw truth about how her marriage is in crisis behind the scenes,¬†</p><p>After spending seven years of being caregivers for her husband&apos;s mother, Toki expected her husband to deeply grieve her death when she passed away in January. What she didn&apos;t anticipate was the rage, anger, and emotional breakdowns that would follow ‚Äì behaviors she&apos;d never witnessed in her husband before. Now she&apos;s wrestling between compassion for his loss while questioning how long she can sustain a marriage that&apos;s fundamentally changed.</p><p>Her breakthrough comes through learning a completely different approach to communication ‚Ä¶ one that comes from her heart instead of her head.¬†</p><p>For anyone balancing professional success with private relationship struggles, this episode offers validation and practical guidance.     <itunes:summary><![CDATA[The hardest truth about addiction and mental health struggles is that families become casualties too. Yet no one talks about their recovery.     <description><![CDATA[<p>The hardest truth about addiction and mental health struggles is that families become casualties too. Yet no one talks about their recovery. Lisa Katona Smith, TEDx speaker and the author of <em>Parallel Recovery</em>, has pioneered a unique approach to healing that recognizes families as the forgotten participants in the recovery process.¬†</p><p>What‚Äôs even more unique is that Lisa‚Äôs approach doesn&apos;t depend on whether the struggling person wants to change or not. Instead, Lisa advocates for what she calls &quot;loving better&quot;‚Äîa combination of sustainability and connection that allows families to maintain healthy boundaries while staying emotionally present for their struggling loved one.¬†</p><p>Through structured reflection, strong communication tools, and addressing the underlying fears that drive reactive parenting, Lisa shows that families can learn to create an environment where healing becomes possible for everyone involved.</p><p>If you or anyone you know is a parent who‚Äôs trying to navigate the complex terrain of adolescent mental health challenges, this episode can change your world. It emphasizes the importance of curiosity over interrogation, validation over toxic positivity, and the recognition that sometimes the most loving thing parents can do is examine their own triggers and responses rather than focusing solely on changing their child&apos;s behavior.</p><p><b>About Lisa</b></p><p>Lisa Katona Smith, M.Ed., is a TEDx speaker, educator, and author of Parallel Recovery‚Äîa family-centered model that empowers loved ones to heal alongside someone facing mental health and substance use challenges. Known for her clarity, compassion, and systems-level insight, Lisa helps families and professionals build sustainable, connection-based recovery through consulting, training, and transformative conversations.</p><p><b>Connect with Lisa</b></p><p>You can connect with Lisa on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/lisa-katona-smith-985b48212/'>Lisa Katona Smith</a> and on Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/parallel_recovery/'>Parallel Recovery</a>.¬† To find out how to work with Lisa visit her website at <a href='https://lisakatonasmith.com/'>Lisa Katona Smith</a> and catch her TEDx Talk <a href='https://youtu.be/bAguAjVzE7o?si=lZaKb3JsDM3jSgXo'>The Power Of Parallel Recovery</a>.</p><p><b>Just Released</b></p><p><a href='https://a.co/d/0jd8jOY'>Parallel Recovery - A Guide For Those Who Love Someone With Substance Use Disorder</a></p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <itunes:title>How to Create an Airtight High Conflict Parenting Plan </itunes:title>
    <title>How to Create an Airtight High Conflict Parenting Plan </title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[The moment you‚Äôre begging over a $72 reimbursement is the moment you realize the paperwork isn‚Äôt the problem‚Äîthe power dynamic is. That‚Äôs exactly what Samantha Boss, high-conflict parenting coach and mediator, discovered. Now, Samantha helps other moms who are battling high conflict divorces design airtight high conflict pare...]]></itunes:summary>
    <description><![CDATA[<p>The moment you‚Äôre begging over a $72 reimbursement is the moment you realize the paperwork isn‚Äôt the problem‚Äîthe power dynamic is. That‚Äôs exactly what Samantha Boss, high-conflict parenting coach and mediator, discovered. Four years, three attorneys, five judges, and over $100k+ later Samantha‚Äôs initial ‚Äúthis is just paperwork‚Äù mindset morphed into years of litigation and financial abuse. Now, Samantha helps other moms who are battling high conflict divorces design airtight high conflict parenting plans built for conflict, not fantasy.¬†</p><p>The difference between ‚Äústandard parenting plans‚Äù and a high-conflict one isn&apos;t just a few extra pages. While typical parenting plans run from 4 -10 pages with a lot of vague, boilerplate language, Samantha‚Äôs detailed plans span 18-30 pages and cover everything from &quot;diapers to diplomas.&quot;¬†</p><p>In this podcast episode Samantha reveals the psychology behind negotiating with difficult exes, how to choose a lawyer who really understands high conflict divorce, and how to choose your divorce process intentionally.</p><p>If you‚Äôre embroiled in a high conflict divorce, and you have children, this episode is pure gold.</p><p><b>About Samantha</b></p><p>As a certified divorce mediator and coach, Samantha empowers moms to protect themselves and their children&apos;s future by providing expert guidance on parenting plans and navigating high-conflict exes.¬†</p><p><b>Connect with Samantha</b></p><p>You can connect with Samantha on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/samantha-boss-857a1b138'>Samantha Boss</a> and on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/theuglytruthofdivorce'>The Ugly Truth of Divorce</a>.     <description><![CDATA[<p>Roxanne had listened to her husband&apos;s money threats for years, but when he mentioned creating trusts to cut her out, something inside her snapped. She filed for divorce the next day.</p><p>Yet, after 33 years of marriage, leaving is still hard ‚Äì in spite of the fact that her marriage has been over for years. Unfortunately, Roxanne‚Äôs husband refuses to accept reality, leaving her to navigate the treacherous waters of a gray divorce while trying to protect herself both financially and physically.</p><p>What makes Roxanne&apos;s situation particularly complex is that her husband is an alcoholic and is in complete denial about the divorce. With guns in the house and her 30-year-old son serving as an unintentional buffer, Roxanne must carefully balance her safety with the practical challenges of untangling decades of separate finances and preparing for a battle over assets.¬†</p><p>Her story reveals the hidden struggles many face when leaving a long-term marriage, especially when one spouse will do anything to maintain the status quo.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <description><![CDATA[<p>When your financial world gets turned upside down, the last thing you want is to feel powerless. That‚Äôs why Lauren Connelly, a wealth advisor with over a decade of experience, devotes her career to helping women and families navigate major life transitions like divorce, retirement, and estate planning so that they have enough money after divorce to live comfortably.</p><p>Growing up with a single mother who worked tirelessly to rebuild after divorce, Lauren brings both professional expertise and personal insight into why financial clarity and confidence matter so much during times of change, particularly divorce.</p><p>Lauren explains how she first saw the power of financial education while working in retirement planning, where she met countless people‚Äîespecially women‚Äîwho were suddenly forced to take charge of money decisions they‚Äôd never handled before. She makes it clear that understanding the basics, even if you‚Äôre not ‚Äúa numbers person,‚Äù can transform fear into empowerment.¬†</p><p>Lauren stresses that financial planning isn‚Äôt just about numbers‚Äîit‚Äôs about your life goals. Whether you‚Äôre figuring out if you can sustain yourself after divorce, planning to retire comfortably, or simply wanting a second opinion, she emphasizes the value of asking the right questions and finding an advisor who truly fits you. Most importantly, she shows how financial planning, done right, helps you build a future that supports not just your wealth, but your freedom and peace of mind.</p><p><b>About Lauren</b></p><p>Lauren Connelly is a Wealth Management Advisor at Vestor Capital with 10+ years of experience. Lauren is dedicated to assisting clients in growing and protecting their assets so they can achieve what matters most to them.</p><p>Lauren, a CFP¬Æ professional, believes that fear drives financial decisions too often.     <description><![CDATA[<p>&quot;Your divorce doesn&apos;t define you.&quot; These powerful words from divorce recovery coach Leah Marie Mazur capture the essence of her transformative approach to healing after divorce. Leah Marie brings raw authenticity to the table, sharing how her own journey through three divorces led to profound self-discovery and eventually, to her calling to help other women, especially moms, to rebuild self-esteem, set boundaries, and navigate both divorce recovery and co-parenting with confidence.</p><p>Leah Marie emphasizes that divorce recovery isn&apos;t just about getting over the end of your marriage. It&apos;s about understanding your patterns, taking ownership of your role, and learning to meet your own needs so you don&apos;t rely on others to fill emotional voids.¬†</p><p>Leah Marie and co-founder Samantha Boss also created the Next Chapter membership, a private community and resource hub specifically for women dealing with high-conflict divorces and co-parenting struggles. The platform offers practical tools, compassionate support, and the reminder that divorce is not who you are, it‚Äôs just one chapter in your story.</p><p><b>About Leah</b></p><p>Leah Marie Mazur is a Certified Divorce Recovery Coach, and the founder of Mindfully Ready and co-creator of The Next Chapter membership. She specializes in helping divorced moms heal, rebuild self-esteem, and co-parent with confidence after high-conflict breakups. Through coaching, courses, and community, Leah empowers women to set boundaries, prioritize themselves, and create fulfilling new chapters in life. Her own experience of navigating three divorces fuels her passion for guiding women through recovery with compassion and proven strategies.</p><p><b>Connect with Leah</b></p><p>You can connect with Leah Marie on LinkedIn at <a href='http://www.linkedin.com/in/MindfullyReady'>Mindfully Ready</a> and on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/mindfullyready/'>Mindfully Ready</a>.     <description><![CDATA[<p>What if the secret to successful post-divorce dating isn&apos;t about perfecting your dating profile, but about understanding the three crucial criteria that most people completely ignore?¬†</p><p>In this podcast episode, love coach Laurie Gerber reveals her revolutionary &quot;3-H method&quot; that has helped countless women over 50 navigate the treacherous waters of modern dating. As someone who saved her own marriage from the brink of divorce (now 26 years strong) before becoming a professional coach, Laurie brings unique insight to relationship challenges.</p><p>Laurie and I dive deeply into WHEN and HOW you should start dating again after divorce [SPOILER ALERT: It&apos;s not when you think!]. We also talk about how to avoid the most common pitfalls that will keep you stuck in dating limbo.</p><p>Finally, we discuss how to navigate the modern maze of online dating and how to master the progression from digital banter to video chats to live dates.¬†</p><p>This episode is full of helpful tips and down-to-earth advice that will leave you feeling empowered to dive back into the dating world with confidence. As Laurie says, it‚Äôs never too late to find love ‚Ä¶ but only if you start by doing your own inner work first.</p><p><b>About Laurie</b></p><p>Laurie Gerber is one of the most engaging and effective life coaches and presenters in the country.</p><p>After holding several positions at Handel Group¬Æ over the last 20 years, including President of HG Life, Laurie is currently licensing The Handel Method¬Æ and running Laurie Gerber Coaching, Inc. focusing on LOVE coaching.</p><p>Laurie has appeared on the Today Show, Dr, Phil, MTV and A &amp; E and been the resident love expert at Match, Zoosk, Jdate, and many more.</p><p>She has been presenting to and coaching individuals, couples, and groups, with a wide range of partners including: the dating sites above, General Assembly, She Tribe, BeSocialChange, IvyConnect, Ellevate, and many more.     <title>Finding Love After 50: Strategies From a Matchmaking Pioneer</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[What if the key to finding love after 50 isn't about getting lucky, but about getting strategic?     <description><![CDATA[<p>What if the key to finding love after 50 isn&apos;t about getting lucky, but about getting strategic? Andrea McGinty, known as the <em>‚ÄúGodmother of Modern Dating,‚Äù</em> discovered this truth firsthand after being dumped at the altar in her twenties. That devastating moment sparked the creation of <em>It&apos;s Just Lunch</em> - a revolutionary matchmaking service that grew to over 110 locations worldwide and facilitated more than 10,000 marriages.</p><p>Andrea later sold that company and created ‚Äú<em>33,000 Dates</em>,‚Äù a dating service that focuses specifically on helping people over 45 navigate the complex world of online dating with scientific precision and proven strategies.</p><p>Andrea harnesses the power of data analytics and algorithms to sift through thousands of potential online matches for her clients. Her approach combines cutting-edge research with old-school relationship wisdom, using everything from demographic data to red-flag identification techniques.¬†</p><p>Her results speak for themselves: 65% of Andrea&apos;s current clients end up in long-term relationships, and more than 40% of today&apos;s top matchmakers trace their expertise back to her pioneering methods.¬†</p><p>Andrea‚Äôs latest book, <em>&quot;Second Acts: Winning Strategies for Dating Over 50,&quot;</em> distills decades of Andrea‚Äôs experience into 166 no-nonsense strategies, complete with worksheets and QR codes for interactive guidance.¬†</p><p>From understanding why AI-written profiles fail spectacularly to learning the optimal number of dating sites to use at once, Andrea&apos;s systematic approach transforms the overwhelming world of modern romance into a manageable, strategic process that actually works.</p><p><b>About Andrea</b></p><p>About Andrea McGinty is known as The Godmother of Modern Dating and her journey is as compelling as the love stories she‚Äôs helped create.¬† After being dumped at the altar in her 20s, Andrea founded It‚Äôs Just Lunch Matchmaking in 1990.¬† Andrea revolutionized the matchmaking industry. Her innovative service grew to over 110 locations worldwide and facilitated over 33,000 setups, resulting in more than 10,000 marriages. Today, her company, 33,000 Dates, focuses on helping the over-45 crowd find love in the second act of their lives.¬†</p><p>Andrea has been featured on Oprah, People, Today Show, and named Entrepreneur of the Month on the Early Show. As a sought-after speaker, she has addressed audiences at the American Marketing Association and other prestigious events. Her insights and passion have made her a trusted voice in the realm of love and relationships. ¬†</p><p><b>Connect with Andrea</b></p><p>You can connect with Andrea on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/andrea-mcginty-a2bba8116/'>Andrea McGinty</a> and on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/33ThousandDates'>33 Thousand Dates</a>.¬† You can follow Andrea on Instagram at <a href='http://www.instagram.com/33000dates'>33000dates</a> and on YouTube at <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@33thousanddates47'>33000dates</a>.¬† To find out how to work with Andrea visit her website at <a href='https://www.33000dates.com/'>33 Thousand Dates</a>.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>What if the key to finding love after 50 isn&apos;t about getting lucky, but about getting strategic? Andrea McGinty, known as the <em>‚ÄúGodmother of Modern Dating,‚Äù</em> discovered this truth firsthand after being dumped at the altar in her twenties. That devastating moment sparked the creation of <em>It&apos;s Just Lunch</em> - a revolutionary matchmaking service that grew to over 110 locations worldwide and facilitated more than 10,000 marriages.</p><p>Andrea later sold that company and created ‚Äú<em>33,000 Dates</em>,‚Äù a dating service that focuses specifically on helping people over 45 navigate the complex world of online dating with scientific precision and proven strategies.</p><p>Andrea harnesses the power of data analytics and algorithms to sift through thousands of potential online matches for her clients. Her approach combines cutting-edge research with old-school relationship wisdom, using everything from demographic data to red-flag identification techniques.¬†</p><p>Her results speak for themselves: 65% of Andrea&apos;s current clients end up in long-term relationships, and more than 40% of today&apos;s top matchmakers trace their expertise back to her pioneering methods.¬†</p><p>Andrea‚Äôs latest book, <em>&quot;Second Acts: Winning Strategies for Dating Over 50,&quot;</em> distills decades of Andrea‚Äôs experience into 166 no-nonsense strategies, complete with worksheets and QR codes for interactive guidance.¬†</p><p>From understanding why AI-written profiles fail spectacularly to learning the optimal number of dating sites to use at once, Andrea&apos;s systematic approach transforms the overwhelming world of modern romance into a manageable, strategic process that actually works.</p><p><b>About Andrea</b></p><p>About Andrea McGinty is known as The Godmother of Modern Dating and her journey is as compelling as the love stories she‚Äôs helped create.¬† After being dumped at the altar in her 20s, Andrea founded It‚Äôs Just Lunch Matchmaking in 1990.¬† Andrea revolutionized the matchmaking industry. Her innovative service grew to over 110 locations worldwide and facilitated over 33,000 setups, resulting in more than 10,000 marriages. Today, her company, 33,000 Dates, focuses on helping the over-45 crowd find love in the second act of their lives.¬†</p><p>Andrea has been featured on Oprah, People, Today Show, and named Entrepreneur of the Month on the Early Show.     <title>The Money Mistakes Most Women Make Without Realizing It</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[What if the biggest threat to your financial future isn't market crashes or economic downturns, but simply not being part of the conversation?     <description><![CDATA[<p>What if the biggest threat to your financial future isn&apos;t market crashes or economic downturns, but simply not being part of the conversation? In her 25 years of working within the financial services industry, Dr. Barbara Provost discovered that women‚Äôs financial needs (including the need for a financial education) were being largely ignored. As a result, women were making money mistakes they didn&apos;t need to make. She and her daughter Maggie Nielsen are now on a mission to change that.¬†</p><p>Together, they operate Purse Strings, an organization designed to provide women with clear, practical financial education and connect them with vetted professionals who understand their unique challenges. Whether it‚Äôs preparing for retirement, navigating divorce, or recovering from unexpected loss, Dr. Provost and Maggie focus on helping women make confident, informed financial decisions during major life transitions and beyond.</p><p>In this podcast episode, we dive deeply into the most common and costly financial mistakes women make - like staying out of financial conversations, undervaluing their contributions, or trusting advisors who don‚Äôt engage with them. We also talk about simple, practical steps you can take to start regaining control of your financial future, and to build the right support team who will help you do that.</p><p>If you‚Äôre feeling uncertain about your finances (especially if you‚Äôre facing a divorce!) this podcast episode is a great first step toward building the secure financial future you dream about.</p><p><b>About Dr. Barbara &amp; Maggie</b></p><p>Dr. Barbara Provost and Maggie Nielsen are a dynamic mother-daughter duo committed to empowering women with the tools they need to make confident financial decisions. As a consultant, educator, and entrepreneur, Barbara connects women with trusted financial professionals to help them plan for a future full of choices. Maggie, with her curious mindset and passion for personal growth, inspires others through motivational talks and equips women with the financial knowledge they need to thrive. Together, they are dedicated to helping women build lives free from financial stress thanks to the support of their community of trusted professionals.</p><p><b>Connect with Dr. Barbara &amp; Maggie</b></p><p>You can connect with Dr. Barbara &amp; Maggie on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/company/pursestrings/'>Purse Strings</a> and on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/pursestringsco'>Purse Strings</a>.     <description><![CDATA[<p>What if everything you think you know about divorce and your money is keeping you trapped in financial anxiety? Phil Telpner, a financial advisor, former hedge fund manager, and president of Breakout Private Wealth, reveals why even women with substantial assets find themselves paralyzed by money decisions during and after their divorce. He also reveals the simple system he created that will turn that around.</p><p>Phil breaks down the most common questions women face post-divorce: ‚ÄúCan I?‚Äù, ‚ÄúHow much?‚Äù, and ‚ÄúWhat if?‚Äù. He also reveals how you can turn your answers to these questions into the foundation of a strong financial plan.¬†</p><p>Phil also unpacks the hidden landmines that can derail your financial future after divorce, including maintenance changes due to job loss, and the tax implications that come with switching your filing status post-divorce.¬†</p><p>Phil challenges conventional financial wisdom and offers practical strategies for maximizing your wealth and minimizing your financial risks after your divorce. His insights offer a lifeline for women who want to build financial security while modeling financial strength for their children.¬†</p><p>Throughout this episode, Phil‚Äôs message is clear: Action eliminates anxiety. You don‚Äôt need to have every financial issue figured out from the start. You just need to take your next best step.</p><p><b>About Phil</b></p><p>Phil helps recently divorced women take their finances from overwhelm and anxiety to opportunity.¬† He is the author &quot;Million Dollar Divorce- How To Avoid Money Anxiety After Divorce, Without Sacrificing Your Lifestyle) and the &quot;Gen X Guide To Financial Independence&quot; Husband, Dad, Financial Advisor, Owner Breakout Private Wealth.</p><p><b>Connect with Phil</b></p><p>You can connect with Phil on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/breakoutprivatewealth/'>Phil Telpner</a>.¬† To explore how Phil can help you achieve your goals visit his website at <a href='https://breakoutprivatewealth.com/'>Breakout Private Wealth</a>.¬† You can email Phil at pt@breakoutprivatewealth.com</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <itunes:title>Real Self-Care that Works When Your Life is Falling Apart</itunes:title>
    <title>Real Self-Care that Works When Your Life is Falling Apart</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[What if the biggest threat to your health isn't cancer or heart disease, but something hiding in plain sight that you do every single day?     <description><![CDATA[<p>What if the biggest threat to your health isn&apos;t cancer or heart disease, but something hiding in plain sight that you do every single day? Chronic stress ‚Äì especially the stress that comes with major life events like divorce or a demanding career, can trigger autoimmune conditions, adrenal fatigue, and thyroid problems. Health coach Jennifer Gilman, who‚Äôs known as the <em>Self-Care Muse</em>, knows that reality all too well.</p><p>In this podcast episode, Jennifer shares her journey from a burned-out entrepreneur who was experiencing debilitating fatigue, cognitive impairment, and full-body tremors to someone who is now vibrantly alive.</p><p>The real power of this conversation, though, lies in the practical, no-cost self-care strategies that Jennifer shares to turn your health around. (And yes, we go way beyond the typical ‚Äútake a bubble bath‚Äù advice!)</p><p>We also dive into the science of what‚Äôs really happening in the body when we‚Äôre exhausted, anxious, or foggy‚Äîand why symptoms like these are often dismissed or misdiagnosed. From thyroid crashes to cognitive shutdown, Jennifer connects the dots between emotional stress and physical breakdowns in a way that‚Äôs both accessible and eye-opening.</p><p>Whether you‚Äôre in the thick of a divorce or just trying to reclaim your health, Jennifer offers a grounded path forward that starts with small, consistent steps‚Äîand gives you permission to rebuild your life, one moment at a time.</p><p><b>¬†About Jennifer</b></p><p>Jennifer Gilman, is a National Board-Certified Health &amp; Wellness Coach and the visionary force behind New Way Health Coach. After a 26-year corporate career marked by autoimmune struggles and burnout, Jennifer transformed her own health‚Äîand now helps others do the same through science-backed, deeply personalized coaching. She and her team specialize in one-on-one coaching and corporate wellness, blending functional medicine with intuitive, real-world strategies. Known as the ‚Äúself-care muse,‚Äù Jennifer inspires lasting change and empowers clients to reclaim their energy, focus, and well-being.</p><p><b>Connect with Jennifer</b></p><p>You can connect with Jennifer on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/jennifer-gilman-36953a248/'>Jennifer Gilman</a> and on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/NewWayHealthCoach'>New Way Health Coach</a>.¬† You can follow Jennifer on her YouTube channel at <a href='https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCmYZzgkm2ETB-8SmCEq8Qyg?view_as=subscriber'>New Way Health Coach</a> and on Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/newwayhealthcoach/'>New Way Health Coach</a>.¬† To find out more about Jennifer‚Äôs work or to schedule a Discovery call for 1:1 coaching visit her website at <a href='https://newwayhealthcoach.com/'>New Way Health Coach</a>.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <title>How to Get Divorce Support with the AARP of Divorce</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[What happens when your child support payments suddenly stop because your ex lost his/her job? Most divorced parents have no safety net to help them in this scenario. But Ron Platt, co-founder and CEO of the National Association for Single and Divorced Families (NASDF), aims to change that ‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs just ONE of the divorce support benefits that the NASDF provides. The NASDF operates like the "AARP of divorce," providing a membership-based organization that offers an umbrella of discounted s...]]></itunes:summary>
    <description><![CDATA[<p>What happens when your child support payments suddenly stop because your ex lost his/her job? Most divorced parents have no safety net to help them in this scenario. But Ron Platt, co-founder and CEO of the National Association for Single and Divorced Families (NASDF), aims to change that ‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs just ONE of the divorce support benefits that the NASDF provides.</p><p>The NASDF operates like the &quot;AARP of divorce,&quot; providing a membership-based organization that offers an umbrella of discounted services, products, and resources specifically designed for those who are divorced, are getting divorced, or are managing single-family households. Among the resources it provides is <b><em>‚ÄúSupport Insured‚Äù</em></b> - the only divorce-specific insurance on the market that protects child support and alimony payments in cases of death, disability, or involuntary unemployment.</p><p>Fueled by his own experiences as a foster care parent and the failure of the family court system to protect children, Ron is on a mission to make life easier for divorced and single-parent families. ¬†</p><p>To discover more about the NASDF and how it can provide you with critical divorce support resources, visit NASDF.org.</p><p><b>About Ron</b></p><p>Ron Platt is the Co-Founder and CEO of the National Association for Single and Divorced Families. They provide an umbrella of products, services, support and resources for people who are getting a divorce, currently divorced or have a single-family household. They also have the proprietary marketing rights to the only divorce product on the market that protects child support and alimony payments if the payee dies, becomes disabled or involuntarily unemployed. Their future advocacy will be geared towards foster care reform and children&apos;s rights.</p><p><b>Connect with Ron</b></p><p>You can connect with Ron on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/ronald-platt-a6b49016/'>Ronald Platt</a> and on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/NASDF.org'>NASDF</a>.¬† You can follow Ron and NASDF on their YouTube channel at <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@NASDForg'>NASDForg</a>, on TikTok at <a href='https://www.tiktok.com/@nasdf.org'>NASDF</a> and on Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/nasdforg/'>NASDFORG</a> and find out more information on the website at <a href='https://www.nasdf.org/'>NASDF</a>.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times. You can check out Karen&apos;s videos on <a href='https://www.youtube.com/@karencovy95'>YouTube</a>.<br/><br/>You can connect with Karen on <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/karencovy/'>LinkedIn</a>, <a href='https://www.facebook.com/KarenCovy'>Facebook</a>, <a href='https://www.instagram.com/karencovylawyer/'>Instagram</a>, <a href='https://twitter.com/KarenCovy'>Twitter</a>, and on her own website at <a href='https://karencovy.com/'>karencovy.com</a>.<br/><br/><br/></p>]]></description>

    <itunes:title>Breaking Toxic Relationship Patterns in Love</itunes:title>
    <title>Breaking Toxic Relationship Patterns in Love</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[Episode Description - Breaking Toxic Relationship Patterns in Love The mysterious patterns that keep showing up in your relationships aren't coincidences ‚Äì they're clues to your family inheritance.     <description><![CDATA[<p><b>Episode Description - Breaking Toxic Relationship Patterns in Love</b></p><p>The mysterious patterns that keep showing up in your relationships aren&apos;t coincidences ‚Äì they&apos;re clues to your family inheritance. Johanna Lynn, founder of the Family Imprint Institute, joins us to reveal how our relationship patterns are blueprinted by two generations of family history through the science of epigenetics.<br/><br/>Ever wonder why criticism feels so devastating? Or why you&apos;re drawn to partners who trigger the same old wounds? Joanna explains how these patterns are coded into our emotional DNA. Through her work creating multi-generational genograms, she helps clients visually map these connections, often leading to profound &quot;aha&quot; moments about why they struggle with certain persistent (and often toxic) relationship patterns.<br/><br/>Johanna also shares her unique perspective on forgiveness. Contrary to conventional wisdom, she suggests that <em>understanding</em> is more powerful than <em>forgiveness</em> for healing relationship wounds. &quot;Forgiveness misses the point,&quot; she explains, offering a radical alternative for restoring balance after betrayal that doesn&apos;t involve staying trapped in guilt or resentment.<br/><br/>Drawing from her own divorce experience, Johanna shares practical strategies for breaking inherited patterns. ‚Äã</p><p>Whether you&apos;re navigating a difficult relationship, healing after divorce, or simply curious about why you keep encountering the same relationship challenges, this conversation offers both immediate insights and long-term hope.</p><p><b>About Johanna</b></p><p>Johanna Lynn is the founder of The Family Imprint Institute, dedicated to helping smart, self-aware people stop repeating the same exhausting relationship patterns‚Äîespecially after divorce. She doesn‚Äôt do surface-level fixes. With nearly two decades of experience decoding the emotional blueprints we inherit from our families, Johanna helps you get to the root of why you show up the way you do in love. So, when you&apos;re ready for your next relationship, you don‚Äôt bring the same old patterns along with you.</p><p><b>Connect with Johanna</b></p><p>You can connect with Johanna on LinkedIn at <a href='https://www.linkedin.com/in/johannalynn/'>Johanna Lynn</a> and on Facebook at <a href='https://www.facebook.com/johanna.lynn.54'>Johanna Lynn</a>.¬† You can follow Johanna on Instagram at <a href='https://www.instagram.com/johanna_rekindle'>Johanna Rekindle</a>.¬† To find out how to work with Johanna visit her website at <a href='http://www.johannalynn.ca/'>Johanna Lynn</a>.¬† And you can join Johanna‚Äôs community at <a href='https://app.heartbeat.chat/rekindle/invitation?code=AJA7J4#landing-page'>Johanna Rekindle</a>.¬† You can also email Johanna at connect@johannalynn.ca.</p><p><br/><b>Karen Covy</b> is a Divorce Coach and Consultant, Lawyer, Author, and Speaker who is dedicated to helping people make the best decisions possible for themselves, their families, and their future - especially in stressful times.     <itunes:title>Scared of Aging Alone? The Truth About Solo Aging</itunes:title>
    <title>Scared of Aging Alone? The Truth About Solo Aging</title>
    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[Aging alone is one of the quiet fears that few people talk about, but that a lot of divorcing people harbor ‚Äì especially those going through a grey divorce. In this podcast episode, Dr. Gerda Maissel, a physician and medical navigator with C-suite healthcare leadership experience, breaks down what solo aging means in a healthcare system that often overlooks or overwhelms patients ‚Äîespecially older women.  From navigating complex diagnoses to making life-or-death decisions, Dr. Maissel ex...]]></itunes:summary>
    <description><![CDATA[<p>Aging alone is one of the quiet fears that few people talk about, but that a lot of divorcing people harbor ‚Äì especially those going through a grey divorce.
